Submodules#

dimcat.analyzer module#

Analyzers are PipelineSteps that process data and store the results in Data.processed.

class dimcat.analyzer.ChordSymbolBigrams(once_per_group=False, dropna=True)[source]#

Bases: ChordSymbolAnalyzer

Analyzer that returns the bigram counts for all valid chord transitions within a group, ordered by descending frequency.

check(df)[source]#

Test piece of data for certain properties before computing analysis.

Returns:

  • bool – True if the passed data is eligible.

  • str – Error message in case the passed data is not eligible.

static compute(expanded: DataFrame, dropna: bool = True) → Series[source]#

Turns the chord column into bigrams and returns their counts in descending order.

Parameters:

  • expanded – Expanded harmony labels.

  • dropna – By default, NaN values are dropped before computing bigrams, resulting in transitions

  • include (from a missing value's preceding to its subsequent value. Pass False to) –

  • values. (bigrams from and to NaN) –

Returns:

The last two index level are unique (from, to) bigrams, Series values are their corresponding counts.

process_data(data: Data) → Data[source]#

Returns a copy of the Data object containing processed data.

str The name of the function that allows displaying one group’s results as a single pandas object. See data.Corpus.convert_group2pandas()

level_names#

dict Define {“indices”: “index_level_name”} if the analysis is applied once per group, because the index of the DataFrame holding the processed data won’t be showing the individual indices anymore.

class dimcat.analyzer.NotesAnalyzer(once_per_group=False)[source]#

class dimcat.analyzer.PitchClassVectors(once_per_group=False, pitch_class_format='tpc', weight_grace_durations: float = 0.0, normalize=False, ensure_pitch_classes=None, include_empty=False)[source]#

Bases: NotesAnalyzer

Analyzer that groups notes by their pitch class and aggregates their durations.

static compute(notes: DataFrame, pitch_class_format='tpc', weight_grace_durations: float = 0.0, normalize=False, ensure_pitch_classes=None)[source]#

Group notes by their pitch class and aggregate their durations.

Parameters:

  • notes (pandas.DataFrame) – Note table to be transformed into a Pitch Class Vector. The DataFrame needs to contain at least the columns ‘duration_qb’ and ‘tpc’ or ‘midi’, depending on pitch_class_format.

  • pitch_class_format (str, optional) –

    Defines the type of pitch classes to use for the vectors.
    ’tpc’ (default): tonal pitch class, such that -1=F, 0=C, 1=G etc.
    ’name’: tonal pitch class as spelled pitch, e.g. ‘C’, ‘F#’, ‘Abb’ etc.
    ’pc’: chromatic pitch classes where 0=C, 1=C#/Db, … 11=B/Cb.
    ’midi’: original MIDI numbers; the result are pitch vectors, not pitch class vectors.

  • weight_grace_durations (float, optional) – By default (0.), grace notes have duration 0. Set this value to include their weighted durations in the computation of PCVs, e.g. 0.5.

  • normalize (bool, optional) – By default, the PCVs contain absolute durations in quarter notes. Pass True to normalize the PCV for each group.

  • ensure_pitch_classes (Iterable, optional) – By default, pitch classes that don’t appear don’t appear. Pass a collection of pitch classes if you want to ensure their presence even if empty. For example, if pitch_class_format='pc' you could pass ensure_columns=range(12).

Return type:

pandas.Series

dimcat.data module#

Class hierarchy for data types.

class dimcat.data.Data(data=None, **kwargs)[source]#

Bases: ABC

Subclasses are the dtypes that this library uses. Every PipelineStep accepts one or several dtypes.

The initializer can set parameters influencing how the contained data will look and is able to create an object from an existing Data object to enable type conversion.

Get the data field in its raw form.

abstract load()[source]#

Load data into memory.

property n_indices#
pipeline_steps#

The sequence of applied PipelineSteps that has led to the current state in reverse order (first element was applied last).

processed: Dict[tuple, Union[Dict[Union[Tuple[str, str], Tuple[str, str, Interval]], Any], List[str]]]#

Analyzers store there result here. Those that compute one result per item per group store {ID -> result} dicts, all others store simply the result for each group. In the first case, group2pandas needs to be specified for correctly converting the dict to a pandas object.

slice_info#

Dict holding metadata of slices (e.g. the localkey of a segment).

sliced#

Dict for sliced data facets.

track_pipeline(pipeline_step, group2pandas=None, indices=None, processed=None, grouper=None, slicer=None)[source]#

Converts the {ID -> processing_result} dict using the method specified in _.group2pandas.

get(as_pandas: bool = Literal[True]) → Union[Series, DataFrame][source]#
get(as_pandas: bool = Literal[False]) → Dict[tuple, Any]

Collects the results of iter() to retrieve all processed data at once.

Parameters:

as_pandas – By default, the result is a pandas DataFrame or Series where the first levels display group identifiers (if any). Pass False to obtain a nested {group -> group_result} dictionary instead.

Returns:

The contents of processed in original or adapted form.

Uses _.iter_facet() to collect and concatenate all DataFrames for a particular facet.

Parameters:

  • unfold (bool, optional) – Pass True if you need repeats to be unfolded.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

get_indices()[source]#

Fills self.pieces with metadata and IDs for all loaded data. This resets previously applied groupings.

get_item(index, what, unfold=False, multiindex=False)[source]#

Retrieve a DataFrame pertaining to the facet what of the piece index. If the facet has been sliced before, the sliced DataFrame is returned.

Parameters:

  • index (tuple) – (corpus, fname) or (corpus, fname, interval)

  • what ({'form_labels', 'events', 'expanded', 'notes_and_rests', 'notes', 'labels',) – ‘cadences’, ‘chords’, ‘measures’, ‘rests’} What facet to retrieve.

  • unfold (bool, optional) – Pass True if you need repeats to be unfolded.

  • multiindex (bool, optional) – By default, has one level, which is a :obj:pandas.IntervalIndex. Pass True to prepend index as an additional index level.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

Retrieve one of the previously applied PipelineSteps, either by index or by type.

Parameters:

  • of_type (PipelineStep, optional) – Return the most recently applied PipelineStep of this type.

Return type:

PipelineStep

get_slice(index, what)[source]#
get_slice_info(ignore_groups=False) → DataFrame[source]#

Concatenates slice_info Series and returns them as a DataFrame.

property is_grouped: bool#
iter(as_pandas: bool = Literal[False], ignore_groups: bool = Literal[False]) → Iterator[Tuple[tuple, Union[Dict[Union[Tuple[str, str], Tuple[str, str, Interval]], Any], Any]]][source]#
iter(as_pandas: bool = Literal[True], ignore_groups: bool = Literal[False]) → Iterator[Tuple[tuple, Union[Series, DataFrame, Any]]]
iter(as_pandas: bool = Literal[False], ignore_groups: bool = Literal[True]) → Iterator[Union[Tuple[Union[Tuple[str, str], Tuple[str, str, Interval]], Any], Any]]
iter(as_pandas: bool = Literal[True], ignore_groups: bool = Literal[True]) → Iterator[Union[Series, DataFrame, Any]]

Iterate through processed data.

Parameters:

  • as_pandas – Setting this value to False corresponds to iterating through .processed.items(), where keys are group IDs and values are results for Analyzers that compute one result per group, or {ID -> result} dicts for Analyzers that compute one result per item per group. The default value (True) has no effect in the first case, but in the second case, the dictionary will be converted to a Series if the conversion method is set in group2pandas.

  • ignore_groups – If set to True, the iteration loop is flattened and does not include group identifiers. If as_pandas is False (default), and the applied Analyzer computes one {ID -> result} dict per group, this will correspond to iterating through the (ID, result) tuples for all groups.

Yields:

The result of the last applied Analyzer for each group or for each item of each group.

iter_facet(what, unfold=False, concatenate=False, ignore_groups=False)[source]#

Iterate through groups of potentially sliced facet DataFrames.

Parameters:

  • what ({'form_labels', 'events', 'expanded', 'notes_and_rests', 'notes', 'labels',) – ‘cadences’, ‘chords’, ‘measures’, ‘rests’} What facet to retrieve.

  • unfold (bool, optional) – Pass True if you need repeats to be unfolded.

  • concatenate (bool, optional) – By default, the returned dict contains one DataFrame per ID in the group. Pass True to instead concatenate the DataFrames. Then, the dict will contain only one entry where the key is a tuple containing all IDs and the value is a DataFrame, the components of which can be distinguished using its MultiIndex.

  • ignore_groups (bool, False) – If set to True, the iteration loop is flattened and yields (index, facet_df) pairs directly. Clashes with the setting concatenate=True which concatenates facets per group.

Yields:

  • tuple – Group identifier

  • dict or pandas.DataFrame – Default: {ID -> DataFrame}. If concatenate=True: DataFrame with MultiIndex identifying ID, and (eventual) interval.

iter_slice_info() → Iterator[Tuple[tuple, DataFrame]][source]#

Iterate through concatenated slice_info Series for each group.

load(directory: Optional[Union[str, List[str]]] = None, parse_tsv: bool = True, parse_scores: bool = False, ms: Optional[str] = None)[source]#

Load and parse all of the desired raw data and metadata.

Parameters:

  • directory (str) – The path to all the data to load.

  • parse_tsv (bool, optional) – By default, all detected TSV files are parsed and their type is inferred. Pass False to prevent parsing TSV files.

  • parse_scores (bool, optional) – By default, detected scores files are not parsed to save time. Call super().__init__(parse_scores=True) if an analyzer needs to access parsed MuseScore XML.

  • ms (str, optional) – If you pass the path to your local MuseScore 3 installation, ms3 will attempt to parse musicXML, MuseScore 2, and other formats by temporarily converting them. If you’re using the standard path, you may try ‘auto’, or ‘win’ for Windows, ‘mac’ for MacOS, or ‘mscore’ for Linux. In case you do not pass the ‘file_re’ and the MuseScore executable is detected, all convertible files are automatically selected, otherwise only those that can be parsed without conversion.

pieces: Dict[Tuple[str, str], Piece]#

IDs and metadata of those pieces that have not been filtered out.:

{(corpus, fname) -> :obj:`ms3.Piece`
slice_facet_if_necessary(what, unfold)[source]#
Parameters:

  • what (str) – Facet for which to create slices if necessary

  • unfold (bool) – Whether repeats should be unfolded.

Returns:

True if slices are available or not needed, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

dimcat.filter module#

A Filter is a PipelineStep that removes indices from the Data.

class dimcat.filter.Filter(keep_empty_groups=False)[source]#

Bases: PipelineStep, ABC

A Filter will process a Data object by removing indices from its list of indices.

abstract criterion(index: tuple, data: Data) → bool[source]#

Takes one index and (potentially) looks it up in the data object to decide whether to keep it (returns True) or filter it out (returns False).

process_data(data: Data) → Data[source]#

Returns a copy of the Data object where the list of indices for each existing group has potentially fewer elements than before.

dimcat.grouper module#

A Grouper is a PipelineStep that groups rows of the Data together into subsets.

class dimcat.grouper.CorpusGrouper(sort=True)[source]#

Bases: Grouper

Groups indices that belong to the same corpus.

criterion(index: tuple, data: Data) → str[source]#

Takes one index and (potentially) looks it up in the data object to return the name of the new group that the corresponding element is attributed to. The name will be appended to the previous group names tuple.

class dimcat.grouper.Grouper(sort=True)[source]#

Bases: PipelineStep, ABC

A Grouper will process a Data object by iterating through the current index groups and introducing subgroups for each. Groupers always work top-down, meaning that they cannot group IDs belonging to different groups.

Concretely, it will turn the {(old_groups) -> [(id)]} dict stored in data.indices into {(*old_groups, new_group) -> [(id)]}.

abstract criterion(index: tuple, data: Data) → str[source]#

Takes one index and (potentially) looks it up in the data object to return the name of the new group that the corresponding element is attributed to. The name will be appended to the previous group names tuple.

filename_factory()[source]#
level_names#

“index_level_name”} so that the DataFrame index level distinguishing the resulting groups has a meaningful name. E.g., for grouping by years, a good index level name could be ‘year’.

Type:

Define {“grouper”

Returns a copy of the Data object where the list of indices for each existing group has been further subdivided into smaller groups.

dimcat.pipeline module#

A Pipeline performs computation iteratively on a List of PipelineSteps.

class dimcat.pipeline.Pipeline(pipeline_steps: List[PipelineStep])[source]#

Bases: PipelineStep

A Pipeline takes at initialization a List of PipelineSteps, and processes the Data by iteratievly feeding the input Data into each PipelineStep in that list.

Note that a Pipeline is itself a PipelineStep, so can be included recursively in another Pipeline.

process_data(data: Data) → Data[source]#

Process the given Data. This will feed the Data iteratively to each PipelineStep contained in its initialized pipeline_steps list.

Parameters:

data (Data) – The input Data on which some computation will be performed.

Returns:

The result of feeding the input Data into each step in this Pipeline. This will be exactly the output from the process_data function of the final PipelineStep.

Return type:

Data

class dimcat.pipeline.PipelineStep[source]#

Bases: ABC

A PipelineStep object is able to transform some data in a pre-defined way.

The initializer will set some parameters of the transformation, and then the process_data function is used to transform an input Data object, returning a copy.

check(_) → Tuple[bool, str][source]#

Test piece of data for certain properties before computing analysis.

Returns:

  • bool – True if the passed data is eligible.

  • str – Error message in case the passed data is not eligible.

Parameters:

data (Data) – The data to be transformed. This should not be altered in place.

Returns:

A copy or view of the input Data, transformed in some way defined by this PipelineStep.

Return type:

Data

required_facets#

Specifies a list of facets (such as ‘notes’ or ‘labels’) that the passed Data object needs to provide.

dimcat.slicer module#

A Slicer is a PipelineStep that cuts Data into segments, effectively multiplying IDs.

class dimcat.slicer.ChordCriterionSlicer(column='chord', contains_str=None, warn_na=False)[source]#

Bases: OnePassFacetSlicer

Create slices based on a particular criterion such that each True row starts a new slice.

The ‘expanded’ labels are not sliced but subselected. For the special case of phrase labels that may actually occur without a new harmony and need slice the table, use PhraseSlicer.

check(facet_df)[source]#

Test piece of data for certain properties before computing analysis.

Returns:

  • bool – True if the passed data is eligible.

  • str – Error message in case the passed data is not eligible.

iter_slices(index, facet_df, column='chord', contains_str=None, warn_na=False)[source]#

Slices the facet_df (e.g. notes or annotations) and iterates through the slices so that they can be stored.

Yields:

  • tuple – The DataFrame’s index with the slice’s quarterbeat interval appended. Will be used to store and look up information on this particular slice.

  • pandas.Series – Information about the slice, especially the feature value(s) based on which the segment has come about, such as the local key. Mainly used for subsequent grouping of slices.

  • pandas.DataFrame – The slice, i.e. a chunk or subselection of facet_df.

class dimcat.slicer.ChordFeatureSlicer(feature='chord', na_values='ffill')[source]#

Bases: OnePassFacetSlicer

Create slices based on a particular feature by grouping adjacent identical values.

Returns:

  • bool – True if the passed data is eligible.

  • str – Error message in case the passed data is not eligible.

iter_slices(index, facet_df, feature='chord', na_values='ffill')[source]#

Slices the facet_df (e.g. notes or annotations) and iterates through the slices so that they can be stored.

Yields:

  • tuple – The DataFrame’s index with the slice’s quarterbeat interval appended. Will be used to store and look up information on this particular slice.

  • pandas.Series – Information about the slice, especially the feature value(s) based on which the segment has come about, such as the local key. Mainly used for subsequent grouping of slices.

  • pandas.DataFrame – The slice, i.e. a chunk or subselection of facet_df.

class dimcat.slicer.FacetSlicer(facet, slice_name, **config)[source]#

Bases: Slicer

A FacetSlicer creates slice information based on one particular data facet, e.g. note lists or annotations.

config#

“slice_level_name”} to give the third index column that contains the slices’ intervals a meaningful name. Define {“slicer”: “slicer_name”} for the creation of meaningful file names.

Type:

Define {“indices”

filename_factory()[source]#
abstract iter_slices(index, facet_df, **config) → Tuple[tuple, Series][source]#

Generates slice intervals and slice_info Series based on facet_df (e.g. notes or annotations) and iterates through them so that they can be stored and then used for slicing the facet.

Yields:

  • tuple – The DataFrame’s index with the slice’s quarterbeat interval appended. Will be used to store and look up information on this particular slice.

  • pandas.Series – Information about the slice, especially the feature value(s) based on which the segment has come about, such as the local key. Mainly used for subsequent grouping of slices.

class dimcat.slicer.LazyFacetSlicer(facet, slice_name, **config)[source]#

Bases: FacetSlicer

A FacetSlicer creates slice information based on one particular data facet, e.g. note lists or annotations.

It is called ‘lazy’ because it does not perform any actual slicing, which will be up to the Data object to do upon request.

abstract iter_slices(index, facet_df, **config) → Tuple[tuple, Series][source]#

Generates slice intervals and slice_info Series based on facet_df (e.g. notes or annotations) and iterates through them so that they can be stored and then used for slicing the facet.

Yields:

  • tuple – The DataFrame’s index with the slice’s quarterbeat interval appended. Will be used to store and look up information on this particular slice.

  • pandas.Series – Information about the slice, especially the feature value(s) based on which the segment has come about, such as the local key. Mainly used for subsequent grouping of slices.

process_data(data: Data) → Data[source]#

Perform a transformation on an input Data object. This should never alter the Data or its properties in place, instead returning a copy or view of the input.

Parameters:

data (Data) – The data to be transformed. This should not be altered in place.

Returns:

A copy or view of the input Data, transformed in some way defined by this PipelineStep.

Return type:

Data

Yields:

  • tuple – The DataFrame’s index with the slice’s quarterbeat interval appended. Will be used to store and look up information on this particular slice.

  • pandas.Series – Information about the slice, especially the feature value(s) based on which the segment has come about, such as the local key. Mainly used for subsequent grouping of slices.

  • pandas.DataFrame – The slice, i.e. a chunk or subselection of facet_df.

class dimcat.slicer.OnePassFacetSlicer(facet, slice_name, **config)[source]#

Bases: FacetSlicer

These slicers use information already available based on the computation of slice intervals and slice_info. Either this computation has left them with chunks already, or the facet does not actually have to be sliced because chunks can be created by subselecting it with the computed intervals.

class dimcat.slicer.PhraseSlicer(warn_na=False)[source]#

Bases: SpecialFacetSlicer

Create slice info from phrase beginnings.

OVERWRITE_FEATURES = ['alt_label', 'chord', 'numeral', 'special', 'form', 'figbass', 'changes', 'relativeroot', 'chord_type', 'chord_tones', 'added_tones', 'root', 'bass_note']#
SPLIT_REGEX = re.compile('\n                            ^(?P<label>\\.?\n                                (?:[a-gA-G](?:b*|\\#*)\\.)?\n                                (?:(?:(?:b*|\\#*)(?:VII|VI|V|IV|III|II|I|vii|vi|v|iv|iii|ii, re.VERBOSE)#

perform_facet_slicing(data: Data) → Data[source]#

This is where the special slicing takes place.

class dimcat.slicer.Slicer[source]#

Bases: PipelineStep, ABC

A Slicer will process a Data object by extracting chunks of rows based on an IntervalIndex, which may potentially result in data points to be duplicated or split in two.

Concretely, it iterates through index groups and, for each Interval to form a slice of a particular piece, creates a new index tuple with the Interval appended.

If created from a facet, the slicer creates a pandas.Series per slice containing metadata for later grouping, and stores it in data.slice_info[(corpus, fname, Interval)]. The slices generated from this can be found in data.sliced[facet][(corpus, fname, Interval)].

class dimcat.slicer.SpecialFacetSlicer(facet, slice_name, **config)[source]#

Bases: LazyFacetSlicer

These facet slicers first gather slice intervals and info and then perform an individual kind slicing afterwards.

dimcat.utils module#

Utility functions that are or might be used by several modules or useful in external contexts.

dimcat.utils.clean_index_levels(pandas_obj)[source]#

Remove index levels “IDs”, “corpus” and “fname”, if redundant.

dimcat.utils.get_composition_year(metadata_dict)[source]#

The logic for getting a composition year out of the given metadata dictionary.

dimcat.utils.grams(list_of_sequences, n=2)[source]#

Returns a list of n-gram tuples for given list. List can be nested. Use nesting to exclude transitions between pieces or other units. Uses: nest_level()

dimcat.utils.interval_index2interval(ix)[source]#

Takes an interval index and returns the interval corresponding to [min(left), max(right)).

dimcat.utils.make_suffix(*params)[source]#

Turns the passed parameter values into a suffix string.

Parameters:

params (str or Collection or number) – Parameters to turn into string components of the returned suffix. None values are ignored. Pairs of the form (str, <param>) are treated specially in that the initial str is treated as a prefix of the string component unless <param> is an empty/None/False value.

Returns:

A suffix string where the passed values are joined together, separated by ‘-‘.

Return type:

str

Examples

>>> make_suffix('str', None, False, {0, 1.})
'-str-False-0|1.0'
>>> make_suffix(['collection', 0], ('zero', 0), ('prefix', 1), ('flag', True))
'-collection|0-prefix1-flag'
dimcat.utils.nest_level(obj, include_tuples=False)[source]#

Recursively calculate the depth of a nested list.

dimcat.writer module#

Writers are pipeline steps that write (potentially processed) data to disk.

class dimcat.writer.TSVWriter(directory, prefix=None, index=True, round=None, fillna=None)[source]#

Bases: PipelineStep

This writer iterates through the processed data (pandas objects) and writes each to a TSV file with a file name individually constructed based on the applied pipeline steps.
